column4: hi, my computer doesn't wanna start up (i suppose problem with /etc/fstab, however it seems allright); i've had this problem before, then fixed with changing /etc/fstab, but it doesn't work now and /etc/fstab is the same as when it was fixed again; any idea? (ubuntu 9.10; clean upgrade from 9.04)
i mean /boot = 150Mb; other partitions aren't changed or so i suppose
no, not what I would consider big.  I had a 750 Gb partition autocheck yesterday, took a while for the mount to come online.

my biggest partition is /home with 602.1Gb; but that has always worked at ubuntu 9.04so i thought that couldn't be a problem; it looks like to have a problem with all disks; any idea howto fix it or so?
What behavior are you getting out of a boot attempt and how long are you giving it before you decide it's not booting?
last time i gave it quite a few minutes (5 or so?) but now i closed it down immediatly, because it should work (last time it worked at once after my fix, but there's nothing to 'fix' anymore)
fstab restored from backup or by typing it back to what it was?
typing back by myself, but the fix i gave fstab worked; i changed uuid's to /etc/sda1 etcetera because i thought that would be the problem and it worked (but now not anymore)
Did you find necessary to do an improper (power off) shutdown?  Cause that would provoke a filesystem check at boot.

well, i already did that before it got not-working; my computer didn't react because a silly game was annoying me and didn't want to close down and i didn't have acces to any option to kill it at all (even ctrl-alt-f1 didn't work; out of range at my screen there) so, yes, it was required then -.-
I'd get in there with a live disk.  You can still mount your drives and (I don't know if it's the problem, but) determine your UUIDs.

i still have the uuid's backed up (from the /etc/fstab file), but i supposed that was the problem; i'm already in a live cd-session; should i put the uuid's back or first check whether they were right?
If you've got em in a file backup, I expect they're right.  I doubt you changed anything about filesystem type, but it might hang things up to have declared an ext4 fs to be a ext3 fs.
i changed nothing it's a ext3 anyway, would that make any difference?
I'd just restore the UIUDs and give it patience for the 600+GB fsck.
why it has always worked (i've not changed that partition anyway) and not anymore? ;) could that be just because of ubuntu 9.10 or the unexpected shutdown?
that's why I suspect it's just going through a long fsck.
